xxl.core.collections.bags

Class AbstractBag<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.collections.bags.AbstractBag<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the elements this bag is able to store.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Bag<E>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ArrayBag, ContainerBag, EmptyBag, ListBag

    public abstract class AbstractBag<E>
extends Object
implements Bag<E>
    This class provides a skeletal implementation of the Bag interface, to minimize the effort required to implement this interface.

    To implement a bag, the programmer needs only to extend this class and provide implementations for the cursor, insert and size methods. For supporting the removal of elements, the cursor returned by the cursor method must additionally implement its remove method.

    The documentation for each non-abstract method in this class describes its implementation in detail. Each of these methods may be overridden if the bag being implemented admits a more efficient implementation.

    See Also:
    Cursor, Function, Iterator

    • Method Detail

      • cursor

        public abstract Cursor<E> cursor()
        Returns a cursor to iterate over the elements in this bag without any predefined sequence. The cursor is specifying a view on the elements of this bag so that closing the cursor takes no effect on the bag (e.g., not closing the bag). The behavior of the cursor is unspecified if this bag is modified while the cursor is in progress in any way other than by calling the methods of the cursor. So, when the implementation of this cursor cannot guarantee that the cursor is in a valid state after modifing the underlying bag every method of the cursor except close() should throw a ConcurrentModificationException.
        Specified by:
        cursor in interface Bag<E>
        Returns:
        a cursor to iterate over the elements in this bag without any predefined sequence.

      • insert

        public abstract void insert(E object)
        Adds the specified element to this bag. This method does not perform any kind of duplicate detection.
        Specified by:
        insert in interface Bag<E>
        Parameters:
        object - element to be added to this bag.

      • size

        public abstract int size()
        Returns the number of elements in this bag (its cardinality). If this bag contains more than Integer.MAX_VALUE elements, returns Integer.MAX_VALUE.
        Specified by:
        size in interface Bag<E>
        Returns:
        the number of elements in this bag (its cardinality).

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Removes all of the elements from this bag. The bag will be empty after this call so that size() == 0.

        This implementation creates a cursor by calling the cursor method and iterates over it, removing each element using the Cursor.remove operation. Most implementations will probably choose to override this method for efficiency.

        Specified by:
        clear in interface Bag<E>

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes this bag and releases any system resources associated with it. This operation is idempotent, i.e., multiple calls of this method take the same effect as a single call. When needed, a closed bag can be implicit reopened by a consecutive call to one of its methods. Because of having an unspecified behavior when this bag is closed every cursor iterating over the elements of this bag must be closed.

        Note: This method is very important for bags using external resources like files or JDBC resources.

        This implementation is given by an empty body.

        Specified by:
        close in interface Bag<E>

      • insertAll

        public void insertAll(Iterator<? extends E> objects)
        Adds all of the elements in the specified iterator to this bag. This method does not perform any kind of duplicate detection. The behavior of this operation is unspecified if the specified iterator is modified while the operation is in progress.

        This implementation iterates over the specified iterator, and inserts each object, in turn.

        Specified by:
        insertAll in interface Bag<E>
        Parameters:
        objects - iterator whose elements are to be added to this bag.

      • query

        public Cursor<E> query(Predicate<? super E> predicate)
        Returns a cursor to iterate over all elements in this bag for which the given predicate returns true. This method is very similar to the cursor method except that its result is determined by a predicate. This implementation filters the result of the cursor method using the following code: 
        
   return size() > 0 ?
       (Cursor<E>)new Filter<E>(cursor(), predicate) :
       new EmptyCursor<E>();
        The default implementation of this method is not very interesting, but the method is very import for some bags. When the data structure that is internally used for storing the elements of this bag is able to handle with queries, this method can be implemented very efficient by passing the query to the data structure. For example a range query on a bag that internally uses a R-tree to store its elements will be more efficient when it is proceed on the R-tree itself.
        Like the cursor returned by the cursor method, this cursor's behavior is unspecified if this bag is modified while the cursor is in progress in any way other than by calling the methods of the cursor.
        Specified by:
        query in interface Bag<E>
        Parameters:
        predicate - a predicate that determines whether an element of this bag should be returned or not.
        Returns:
        a cursor to iterate over all elements in this bag for which the given predicate returns true.
